questions.text: A 56 year old male patient has been on an antipsychotic for the last 2 years. He presents with stereotypical, repetitive and involuntary tic like movements of the face, eyelid spasm, and slow twisting movements of the tongue. Diagnose and identify the proposed mechanism of action of the condition.
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is tardive dyskinesia and the proposed mechanism of action is dopamine receptor supersensitivity.

Tardive dyskinesia is an extrapyramidal side effect (EPSE) of antipsychotic drugs that present after long-term usage. It usually presents after months to years of drug usage. It is more common in the elderly population. It is characterized by orofacial involvement. Stereotypical involuntary, repetitive tic-like movements of the face, eyelid spasm, and slow twisting movements of the tongue are the presenting symptoms. The movements disappear during sleep and may vary in intensity with relation to the degree of emotional distress.

The proposed mechanism of action is dopamine postsynaptic receptor supersensitivity leading to increased nigrostriatal dopaminergic activity. Management of tardive dyskinesia-

  • FDA-approved VMAT2 inhibitors - valbenazine and deutetrabenazine are used as drugs for treatment.
  • Anticholinergics are contraindicated as they worsen the symptoms.
  • Switching patients to clozapine can be effective

Note:

Dystonia - The characteristic symptoms for diagnosis of dystonia are acute onset within 1-5 days of starting treatment. It is more common in the younger population. The proposed mechanism of action is D2 blockade in the nigrostriatal pathway. There is typical involvement of head and neck muscles and presents in a variety of forms, such as torticollis, trismus, “mouth opening” dystonia, grimacing, dysarthria, oculogyric crisis, blepharospasm, and swallowing difficulties.

questions.text: A child was brought to the clinic for evaluation of recurrent urinary tract infections. An intravenous urogram was obtained, as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the intravenous urogram showing the drooping lily sign suggest the presence of a duplicated collecting system.

In a duplicated collecting system often, the ureter that supplies the upper half of the kidney becomes obstructed. Suppose the upper pole collecting system of the kidney is completely obstructed. In that case, only the normally draining lower pole collecting system is visualized on the intravenous urogram and looks like a drooping lily.

The duplicated collecting system is a common congenital anomaly of the urinary tract. It occurs due to the division of the ureter as it ascends upwards from the bladder to the renal parenchyma during the embryological period of life. Thus, the person might have two collecting systems for one kidney.

The Weigert-Meyer law describes the relationship of the upper and lower renal moieties in duplicated collecting systems to their drainage inferiorly: When there are abnormalities associated with duplicating collecting systems,

  • The upper pole moiety drains inferomedially and is most commonly associated with obstruction
  • The lower pole moiety drains superolaterally and is most commonly associated with vesicoureteral reflux.

The illustration given below shows the Weigert-Meyer law.

The lower pole ureter is normally inserted into the bladder. However, the upper pole ureter might have an ectopic insertion in the bladder, urethra, or, vagina. 

Ureteropelvic junction obstruction in a patient with duplicated collecting system can be managed with laparoscopic procedures such as pyeloplasty.

Other options:

Option B: Ureterocele is caused due to the dilatation of the ureter as it passes through the bladder wall. It is visualized as a cobra head deformity on a pyelogram.

The image given below shows the cobra head sign.

Option C: Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease is best visualized on ultrasounds and CT scans where the cyst is usually hypodense in contrast to the renal parenchyma. It may appear hyperdense if there is a hemorrhage present.

The image given below shows CT findings seen in childhood polycystic kidney disease.

Option D: Horseshoe kidney is a common congenital anomaly in which there is a fusion of the inferior poles of both kidneys. It is common in patients with Turner's syndrome.

The image shown below shows CT findings seen in the horseshoe kidney.

questions.text: Identify the brace given below and its use.

choices.text: Anterior spinal hyperextension brace, Dorso-lumbar injury
Sterno-occipital mandibular immobilization brace, cervical spine injury

questions.solution:
The given image shows a sterno-occipital mandibular immobilization (SOMI) brace which is used for cervical spine injuries.

The SOMI brace contains a rigid anterior chest piece connected to rigid shoulder supports by straps across the patient’s back. The mandibular support can be removed during eating. The brace provides good restriction to flexion.

It is indicated in relatively stable injuries to the lower cervical spine, postoperatively for patients with questionable fixation, or in the treatment of cervicothoracic injuries.

 

Other options:

Option A: Scoliosis and kyphosis can be managed with the Milwaukee brace, also known as a cervical-thoracic-lumbosacral orthosis (CTLSO). It contains a pelvic girdle (pelvic mold), bars (superstructures), and a combination of corrective slings and pads that attach to the superstructure. The pelvic girdle locks onto the waist roll and reduces lumbar lordosis, which helps in kyphosis correction.

The image shown below is the Milwaukee brace.

Option B: Anterior spinal hyperextension brace(ASHE brace) is used in dorsolumbar spinal injury. A hyperextension brace will take the pressure off the weak vertebrae and limit forward bending. It is shown in the image below.

Option C: Taylor brace is indicated for stabilization of the spine in dorsolumbar spinal injury. It is designed to control the upper and lower regions of the spinal column and support the spine while standing, sitting, and walking after spinal surgery.

questions.text: A 6-month-old child is brought to the clinic with a common cold and the parents give a  history of stridor, dyspnea, and intercostal retractions shortly after birth. On examination, you notice that he has biphasic stridor.   What is the most probable etiology of this condition?
questions.solution:
The finding of biphasic stridor in this scenario is highly suggestive of congenital subglottic stenosis.

Subglottic stenosis is a congenital or acquired condition characterized by a narrowing of the upper airway extending from just below the vocal folds to the lower border of the cricoid cartilage. 

Congenital subglottic stenosis is the most common cause of biphasic stridor in children. The subglottis is the narrowest part of the upper airway in a child. The symptoms of congenital subglottic stenosis usually present shortly after birth and include biphasic stridor, dyspnea, and suprasternal, intercostal, and diaphragmatic retractions. In this child, edema, and secretions caused by the common cold further narrow the subglottic region, leading to the symptoms.  Abnormal cry, aphonia, or hoarseness occur when the vocal cords are affected. In acquired subglottic stenosis, there is a history of laryngeal insult or prior intubation and symptoms appear 3-4 weeks after the same.

Diagnosis is made by airway radiographs and confirmed by direct laryngoscopy. The percentage of stenosis is determined and graded using the Myer Cotton system from grades I through grade IV, indicating the severity.

Management includes dilatation and endoscopic laser surgery for grades 1 and 2 subglottic stenosis, and laryngotracheal reconstruction with cartilage graft augmentation in grades III and IV subglottic stenosis. Mitomycin C is used in the management of subglottic stenosis post-operatively, in order to prevent re-stenosis.

Other options:

Option A- Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital anomaly causing stridor in a child. which typically presents with low-pitched, inspiratory stridor which is exacerbated by crying and agitation.

Option C- Croup is caused by the parainfluenza virus, and typically presents with symptoms of fever, barking cough, inspiratory stridor, and hoarseness of voice. In severe cases, the child might develop respiratory distress with hypoxia and cyanosis.

Option D- Bilateral vocal cord paralysis can also cause stridor in infants and children. Congenital central nervous system lesions such as Chiari malformations and myelomeningoceles can cause bilateral vocal cord paralysis which leads to respiratory distress, high-pitched inspiratory stridor, and a weak cry. 

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient is brought to the psychiatrist by his mother. She describes him as a strict follower of a rigid schedule every day. He redoes his assignments until they appear perfect to him. He gets annoyed if his schedule is disrupted. The patient bluntly states that he is not doing anything wrong and that his mother is inefficient.  He is unable to complete tasks in time as he strives for perfection. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Rigid and perfectionistic behaviour suggests obsessive-compulsive personality disorder.

Patients with obsessive-compulsive personality disorder often have an obsession with rules, details, regulations, neatness, orderliness, and the achievement of perfection. They can work for long periods provided it is routinized as they generally lack flexibility and are intolerant. They have limited interpersonal skills and are formal and serious and often lack a sense of humor. They however try to please those they consider superior to them and carry out their orders in an authoritarian manner. Additionally, they are indecisive as they fear making mistakes.

Differential diagnosis - outpatients with minor obsessive-compulsive personality traits are not occupationally or functionally impaired.

Other options:

Option B - Obsessive-compulsive disorder unlike obsessive-compulsive personality disorder is associated with obsessions that control the patient's actions. Also, it is associated with recurrent obsessions and compulsions.

Option C - Narcissistic personality trait is characterized by an increased sense of self-importance, grandiosity, and lack of empathy.

Option D - Schizotypal personality trait is characterized by eccentric & odd thoughts, perceptions & behavior, magical thinking, ideas of reference, illusions, and peculiar notions.

questions.text: A mother who is a hairstylist has noted that her baby's hair looks dull, breaks off easily, and is tufted. She brings the child to you and informs you about the past history of seizures. Investigations reveal elevated plasma ammonia levels and argininosuccinate levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is argininosuccinic aciduria due to argininosuccinate lyase deficiency.

It is accompanied by high levels of argininosuccinate levels in blood, CSF, and urine. It is also associated with friable, tufted hair known as trichorrhexis nodosa.

questions.text: The muscle marked as X in the image gets its nerve supply from____.
questions.solution:
The short triangular muscle marked in the posterior part of the elbow joint is the anconeus, it receives its nerve supply from the radial nerve.

It arises from the posterior surface of the lateral epicondyle of the humerus and inserts to the lateral aspect of the olecranon and the proximal quarter of the posterior surface of the shaft of the ulna. The anconeus is an extensor of the elbow.

It receives its vascular supply by branches of the posterior interosseous recurrent artery. Nerve supply is from radial nerve (C6, 7, and 8).

questions.text: Identify the clinical features expected in the karyotyping given below.

choices.text: Epicanthic fold and endocardial cushion defects
Eunuchoid body habitus with abnormally long legs
Rocker bottom feet and umbilical hernia

questions.solution:
The given karyotyping image shows “45 XO” abnormality, which is seen in Turner's syndrome. Streak ovaries and peripheral edema are clinical features of Turner's syndrome.

Other clinical features of Turner's syndrome include short stature, low posterior hairline, broad chest, widely spaced nipples, coarctation of the aorta, bicuspid aortic valve, cubitus valgus, and pigmented nevi.

Turner's syndrome is the most common sex chromosome abnormality in females. The classical karyotype is 45, X. Other variants have structural abnormalities of X chromosomes or mosaic patterns.

Some patients may present during infancy. They mainly present with edema of the dorsum of the hand and foot due to lymphatic stasis. The most important cause of increased mortality in children with Turner's syndrome is cardiac abnormalities. 

Turner's syndrome is a common cause of primary amenorrhea. During embryogenesis, fetal ovaries develop normally and the absence of a second X chromosome leads to accelerated loss of normally formed oocytes. This gets completed by the age of 2. The ovaries are reduced to atrophic fibrous bands without ova and follicles. These are called streak ovaries.

At puberty, they fail to develop secondary sexual characteristics.

Other options:

Option B: Epicanthic folds and endocardial cushion defects are usually seen in Down's Syndrome or Trisomy 21. This is the most common chromosomal abnormality and a major cause of intellectual disability. Clinical features include prominent occiput, intellectual disability, micrognathia, low-set ears, overlapping fingers, simian palmar crease, and congenital heart defects.

Image below shows karyotyping of a patient with Down's syndrome. Note the extra chromosome 21.

Option C: Eunuchoid body habitus with abnormally long legs is usually seen in Klinefelter Syndrome (47, XXY). Clinical features include eunuchoid body habitus, gynecomastia, long arms and legs, mitral valve prolapse, testicular dysgenesis with a small penis, type 2 diabetes mellitus, metabolic syndrome, low IQ, and hypogonadism.

Image below shows clinical features and karyotyping of Klinefelter Syndrome respectively. Note the two X and one Y chromosomes.

Option D: Rocker bottom feet and umbilical hernia are usually seen in Edwards Syndrome, Trisomy 18. Clinical Features are microcephaly, intellectual disability, cleft lip and palate, microphthalmia, polydactyly, cardiac defects, umbilical hernia, renal defects, and rocker bottom feet.

The image below shows karyotyping of a patient with Edwards syndrome. Note the extra chromosome 18.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male patient with diabetic neuropathy, on examination, was found to have a loss of sensation to tap and vibration at low frequency (20 Hz). But he has an intact vibration sense at a higher frequency (200 Hz). Which of the following somatosensory receptors is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Sensations of tap and low-frequency vibration (flutter, 5-40 Hz) are sensed by the Meissner's corpuscles. Hence, a loss of sensation of tap and flutter is most likely due to the disease affecting the Meissner's corpuscles. 

Cutaneous mechanoreceptors: There are four types of mechanoreceptors for sensing touch and pressure. They include:

  • Meissner corpuscles
  • Merkel cells
  • Ruffini corpuscles
  • Pacinian corpuscles 

Meissner corpuscles are dendrites encapsulated in the connective tissue beneath the epidermis of glabrous (non-hairy) skin. They respond to tap and flutter (low-frequency vibration - 5-40Hz). They are rapidly adapting receptors.

Merkel cells are expanded dendritic endings in the epidermis of glabrous (non-hairy) skin. They respond to sustained pressure and touch. They are slowly adapting receptors.

Ruffini's corpuscles are enlarged dendritic endings with elongated capsules in the dermis of glabrous and hairy skin. They respond to stretch and fluttering vibrations. They are slowly adapting receptors.

Pacinian corpuscles are the largest cutaneous mechanoreceptor, measuring about 2mm in length and 1mm in diameter. They are present in the dermis of glabrous (non-hairy) and hairy skin. A Pacinian corpuscle consists of a nerve ending encapsulated by concentric layers of connective tissue, giving it an onion-like appearance. They respond to fast vibration (60-500Hz) and deep pressure. They are rapidly adapting receptors.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman conceived while she was on treatment for bipolar disorder and severe acne. Her baby was born at term with features including microtia, micrognathia, ventriculomegaly,  conotruncal heart defects, and thymic aplasia. Which of the following drugs is responsible for these defects?
questions.solution:
Isotretinoin is the teratogen that is responsible for the above-mentioned defects.

It is a vitamin A derivative that is highly teratogenic when orally administered. It is commonly used to treat cystic nodular acne. It inhibits the migration of neural crest cells during embryogenesis and affects the development of multiple organs. These defects are collectively termed retinoic acid embryopathy.

Specific anomalies may include ventriculomegaly, maldevelopment of the facial bones or cranium, microtia or anotia, micrognathia, cleft palate, conotruncal heart defects, and thymic aplasia or hypoplasia.

Isotretinoin also increases the risk of spontaneous abortions and stillbirths by up to 40% in pregnancies exposed in the first quarter of this medicine. Presenting with pregnancy during treatment with isotretinoin is a failure of prevention strategies.

The guidelines for isotretinoin usage are as follows:

  • Isotretinoin is a teratogenic drug that should not be taken during pregnancy and nursing
  • Patients should take 2 pregnancy tests before starting isotretinoin and take a monthly pregnancy test while on the medication and another test 1 month after stopping the medication.
  • Two forms of birth control should be simultaneously used starting 1 month before treatment, during the entire course of treatment, and for 1 month after ceasing treatment with isotretinoin.

Other options:

Option B: Lithium is used in the treatment of bipolar disorder. It is a teratogen associated with Ebstein's anomaly, which is a rare cardiac condition characterized by severe tricuspid regurgitation and right atrial enlargement.

Option C: Valproic acid is the anti-epileptic which confers the greatest risk to the developing fetus while used in pregnancy. It is associated with an increased risk of neural tube defects in the fetus.

Option D: Tetracyclines are associated with yellowish-brown discolouration of deciduous teeth when used after 25 weeks of gestation.

questions.text:
Among the statements given below, all are true regarding bisphosphonates except that _________.
  1. They are used to treat Paget's disease and hypercalcemia.
  2. They inhibit osteoclast function.
  3. Oral preparations are advised to be taken with food.
  4. They can be used in patients with creatinine clearance of <30 mL/min.
questions.solution:
All of the above statements are true regarding bisphosphonates except statements 3 and 4. Oral preparations are advised to be taken on an empty stomach and are not recommended in patients with creatinine clearance of < 30 mL/min.

Bisphosphonates are analogs of pyrophosphate. They act by directly inhibiting osteoclast function, thus preventing bone resorption. It inhibits bone resorption by inducing apoptosis of osteoclasts and inhibition of the cholesterol biosynthesis pathway. 

They are poorly absorbed from the intestine and have very low bioavailability, which is further reduced upon interaction with food and medication. Hence, bisphosphonates should be taken after an overnight fast, on an empty stomach, and at least 30 minutes before breakfast. 

It is excreted unchanged by the kidneys and it declines proportionally with kidney function and is hence not recommended for patients with a creatinine clearance of less than 30ml/min. 

Bisphosphonates are used to treat Paget's disease, tumor-associated osteolysis, and hypercalcemia. It can also be used to treat osteoporosis, including post-menopausal and steroid-induced osteoporosis.

Oral bisphosphonates can cause adverse effects like gastroesophageal reflux, esophagitis, and esophageal ulcers. Intravenous bisphosphonates are associated with flu-like symptoms. Both oral and intravenous bisphosphonates can cause renal toxicity, hypocalcemia, osteonecrosis of the jaw, and atypical femur fractures.

Because of the adverse effects, oral bisphosphonates are contraindicated in the following settings:

  1. Patients with esophageal disorders such as achalasia cardia, esophageal stricture, Barrett's esophagus, or if they are unable to stay upright for at least 30 minutes after taking the medication.
  2. Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) and an estimated glomerular filtration rate(eGFR) of <30 to 35 mL/min.
  3. After any bariatric surgery in which surgical anastomosis is present in the gastrointestinal (GI) tract.

questions.text:
The laboratory results of a patient with congestive cardiac failure are given below. He does not have any preexisting renal condition. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Urine sodium  18 mEq/L
Urine osmolality 800 mOsm/L of water
Fractional excretion of Na <1%
Urine/plasma creatinine >40
questions.solution:
Based on the history of congestive cardiac failure and given laboratory values, the most likely diagnosis is prerenal acute kidney injury. 

Prerenal acute kidney injury occurs due to reduced renal plasma flow and intraglomerular hydrostatic pressure. Common causes are hypovolemia, liver failure, and congestive heart failure. The kidney has autoregulatory mechanisms to compensate for the decreased blood flow resulting in the retention of sodium and water to preserve blood volume. The urinary sodium and fractional excretion of sodium (FeNa) will be also very low. The ratio of urine creatine/plasma creatinine is usually greater than 40:1. The urinary sodium is generally <20 mEq/L.

Other options: 

Option A: Intrinsic acute kidney injury arises due to injury to the tubules, interstitium, blood vessels, or glomeruli. These include but are not limited to acute glomerulonephritis, vasculitis, sepsis, infections, and malignancies. 

Option C: Nephrotoxic acute kidney injury is a type of intrinsic kidney injury due to direct damage to the tubular cells of the kidney. They can be endogenous toxins such as myoglobin, hemoglobin, and uric acid. Contrast agents, aminoglycosides, and amphotericin B are also implicated.

Option D: Glomerulonephritis can cause intrinsic kidney failure by compromising the filtration barrier and the blood flow within the renal circulation. The FeNA is <1% and urinary sodium is generally <20 mEq/L.

questions.text: While performing the following procedure on a 35-year-old man, at a distance of 1 meter, you find that the red reflex was moving against the movement of the instrument. How will you interpret your findings?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the procedure of retinoscopy (skiascopy) being performed. Since the red reflex moves against the movement of the retinoscope, the patient is interpreted as having myopia of more than 1D.

Interpretation of retinoscopy done at 1 m is as follows:

  • No movement of red reflex - Myopia of 1D
  • With the movement - Emmetropia, hypermetropia, myopia less than 1D
  • Against the movement - Myopia more than 1D

Retinoscopy is an objective method of finding out the refractive error by the method of neutralization.

The patient is made to sit in a dark room, and light is directed onto the patient's eye. If a cycloplegic has been used, the patient can look directly into the light and have the refraction assessed along the actual visual axis.

Neutralization: When the red reflex moves with or against the movement of the retinoscope, we do not exactly know the measure of refractive error. Therefore, to estimate the degree of refractive error, the movement of the red reflex is neutralized by the addition of increasingly convex (+) spherical lenses (when the red reflex was moving with the movement of the retinoscope) or concave (-) spherical lenses (when the red reflex was moving against the movement of the retinoscope).

questions.text: Which of the following is a bioterrorism category C agent?
questions.solution:
Nipah virus is a category C bioterrorism agent.

Bioterrorism is the intentional release or threat of release of biological agents (i.e. viruses, bacteria, fungi, or their toxins) in order to cause disease or death among the human population or food crops and livestock to terrorize a civilian population or manipulate the government. 

The agents of bioterrorism are classified into 3 categories:

Category A bioterrorism agents are those which are easily transmitted from one person to the other and are associated with high mortality rates and thus have the potential to cause major public health impacts.

Examples include Bacillus anthracis, Clostridium botulinum and Yersinia pestis.

Category B bioterrorism agents are those which are moderately easy to disseminate and are associated with moderate morbidity and low mortality rates.

Examples include Coxiella burnetti and Brucella.

Category C bioterrorism agents are those which are emerging pathogens that could be engineered for mass dissemination in the future due to ease of availability, high mortality and morbidity rates, and ease of production and dissemination.

Examples include Nipah and Hanta viruses.

questions.text: A 5-week-old male baby was brought to the pediatrician with complaints of non-bilious vomiting after feeding. A mass could be palpated in the right upper quadrant. Ultrasound of the abdomen showed the thickening of the pylorus muscle. What is the immediate next step of management?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a 5-week-old male infant presenting with non-bilious vomiting after feeding along with the palpation of a mass in the right upper quadrant is suggestive of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. The immediate next step in management is to correct the electrolyte imbalance.

The recurrent vomiting secondary to the gastric outlet obstruction leads to dehydration and hypochloremic hypokalemic alkalosis. This abnormality has to be corrected and adequate rehydration ensured before the surgery is undertaken. Normal saline with 0.15% KCl in 5% dextrose is used for maintenance and correction of the deficit.

Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS), is an uncommon condition in infants characterized by abnormal thickening of the pylorus muscles in the stomach leading to gastric outlet obstruction. It is more commonly seen in first-born male infants. Infants usually present between 2-8 weeks of age with non-bilious projectile vomiting. It is a progressive condition and can be distinguished from other causes of vomiting such as infections because the baby is particularly hungry. 

During the test feed, gastric peristalsis moving from left to right of the upper abdomen is visible, and in a relaxed baby, an olive-shaped mass can be palpated in the right upper quadrant.

IHPS can be diagnosed clinically and confirmed by an ultrasound. The diagnostic criteria for pyloric stenosis are a muscle thickness of ≥4 mm and a pyloric length of ≥16 mm. The sonographic appearance of the hypertrophied pylorus resembles that of the uterine cervix and is sometimes referred to as the cervix sign. Double-layered hypertrophic mucosa protrudes into the stomach, creating the so-called nipple sign (given in the image below).

A radiograph may show the presence of an enlarged gastric gas bubble (single bubble). 

 

Surgery can be done once the electrolyte imbalance is corrected. Routine preoperative evaluation is conducted, oral feeding is discontinued and the stomach is emptied with a nasogastric tube. Intravenous fluids are given to replace the ongoing gastric losses.

The hypertrophic pylorus is corrected by Ramstedt’s pyloromyotomy. Postoperatively, intravenous fluids are continued until oral feeding is established in 24 hours. This surgery is the definitive management of this condition and has no long-term sequelae.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman was brought to the casualty ward with a history of head trauma due to a road traffic accident (RTA).  Her eye opens to pain, she moans, and she can localize the site of pain in both hands. On examination, both her pupils are reactive to light. While calculating her GCS-P score, what is the score you would give for pupil reactivity?
questions.solution:
Her pupil reactivity score is 0 since both her pupils are reactive to light.

P0- neither pupil is unreactive to light. (Both pupils are reactive to light)

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), and now, it is referred to as GCS-P. P stands for "pupils unreactive to light"

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

The scoring is as follows- 

  • Both pupils unreactive to light -2
  • One pupil unreactive to light -1
  • Neither pupil unreactive to light (both pupils react to light) -0

The GCS (Glasgow Coma Scale) of this patient is E2V2M5, which comes to a total score of 9. The P score is 0. Hence the GCS-P score is also 9. (E2V2M5P0)

  • E2- Eye opens to pain
  • V2- Moans
  • M5- Localizes to pain on both hands

  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: Which of the following is the usual site for fixed drug eruptions caused by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAID)?
questions.solution:
The common sites for fixed drug eruption caused by NSAIDs are the genitals and lips.

Fixed drug eruption (FDE) is a cutaneous adverse drug reaction characterized by recurrent well-defined lesions occurring in the same sites each time the offending drug is taken. 

It is a classical delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction mediated by resident skin T cells. The common drugs implicated in FDE are non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, co-trimoxazole, tetracyclines and paracetamol.

Drug‐specific clinical patterns have been reported. These include the following:

  • NSAID‐induced FDE - genitals and lips
  • Tetracycline and trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole‐induced FDE - genitals
  • Metamizole‐induced FDE - trunk and extremities
  • Carbocysteine‐induced FDE - face

 The image shown below is of a healed fixed drug eruption on the glans penis.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is a contraindication for endoscopic sinus surgery?
questions.solution:
Subperiosteal abscess is a contraindication for functional endoscopic sinus surgery.

The endoscopic approach is contraindicated in the presence of an intracranial complication of acute infection such as:

  • Meningitis
  • Subperiosteal abscess
  • Epidural abscess
  • Cavernous sinus thrombosis
  • Any visual loss 

Endoscopic sinus surgery is indicated in the following conditions:

  • Long-term treatment of chronic bacterial rhinosinusitis
  • Acute and recurrent rhinosinusitis
  • Nasal polyposis
  • Mucocele
  • Allergic fungal sinusitis with mycetoma
  • Repair of cerebrospinal fluid leak
  • Choanal atresia
  • Septal and turbinate surgeries.

questions.text: An insured 35-year-old woman, who is working in a newspaper establishment, is undergoing a tubectomy procedure. According to the Employees State Insurance Act, she would receive the cash benefit under ____.
questions.solution:
Insured persons in the productive age group undergoing sterilization procedures such as tubectomy and vasectomy are offered cash benefit under the ESI Act as enhanced sickness benefit. 

The enhanced sickness benefit equal to full wage is payable to insured persons undergoing sterilization for 7 days for male and 14 days for female workers. 

Other options: 

Option B: Extended sickness benefit is offered to insured people who are suffering from certain chronic diseases, for a maximum period of 2 years, in addition to the 91 days of leave they are entitled to under the sickness benefit. During this period, they are paid about 80% of the average daily wages. The insured person should have been working for a continuous period of 2 years. There are 34 listed diseases for which the extended sickness benefit can be availed. 

Option C: Maternity benefit is payable in cash to an insured woman for confinement/miscarriage or sickness arising out of pregnancy, confinement, or premature birth of a child or miscarriage. The benefit is allowed at full wages for a period of 26 weeks for confinement, 6 weeks for miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of confinement.

Option D: Dependant's benefit is offered to the dependants of an insured person who died as a result of an employment injury. Pension up to 90% of daily wages is paid to the dependants on a monthly basis. Children are entitled to this benefit up to 18 years of age. 

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

  • Defence 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.
  • Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.
  • Healthy-work force.
